review: I have a lot to say about this book! First of all, I want to mention I listened to it as an audio book and the reader, Caroline Lee, is the best readeI have a lot to say about this book! First of all, I want to mention I listened to it as an audio book and the reader, Caroline Lee, is the best reader I have ever listened to. She has a beautiful Australian accent and she does individual voices without it being distracting in any way. Usually I listen to audio books out of convenience, but in this case I think the book was actually enhanced by the reader.The book alternates between events that took place after the barbecue and events that took place the day of the barbecue. The event was a turning point in all their lives, but the reader doesn't understand why until about half way through the book. At one point I got really tired of not knowing what happened at the barbecue. I felt like the author took it too far, because I was beyond curious or interested, I was almost annoyed. Then after I found out about the barbecue I thought the book slowed quite a bit due to lack of suspense. I decided the book was just "okay."Then as the book went on, and I thought it was going to be over several times because it seemed "wrapped up" to me, the longer it went the more I enjoyed it. One of the themes that the book accentuates in the end is, "I choose my marriage." There is a conversation between a husband and wife (I don't want to give anything away) where they both "choose their marriage," and the conversation is the most poignant little conversation but it exemplifies all that a marriage should be: fun, silly, yet intentional, and hard.The characters are so memorable. I loved them all but my favorite is Vid, a loud boisterous Russian man whose outlook on life is positive and enthusiastic. I identified most with the character of Clementine, who is a little free-spirited and able to cruise through life easily, and sometimes has a hard time realizing others take things a little harder. But I also loved Tiffany, and Sam... anyway I guess I liked them all.There are many issues addressed in this novel, through the various characters and their vastly different lives, so I learned a lot. Hoarding, stripping, cello playing, infertility, CPR, and foster parenting to name a few, but parenting in general is probably the main theme. As an author I might be afraid to include so many issues in one novel, but Moriarty does it seamlessly. There is unnecessary profanity in this book (is it ever necessary?) and her curse word of choice is the f-word. I did tire of hearing it but to me somehow the quality of the writing overshadows the language.I have now read What Alice Forgot and Truly Madly Guilty by Moriarty and in both books she captures marriage so well. It's hard, and it's work, but it's not restraining. She paints a picture of marriage as something that must be allowed to grow and blossom before it can be fully appreciated. Now I plan to read all of her books. I see life through the same lens as Liane Moriarty and I'm positive we would be good friends if we could only meet and get to know each other.
